Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old female admitted with acute mental status changes (AMS), alcoholic hepatitis, and gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). The patient was extubated and is now maintaining on room air. There is improvement in her mental status. The patient has sputum production and a possible infiltrate on chest X-ray, for which she has been started on empirical antibiotics. She received a liter of normal saline bolus to maintain fluid balance and has been advanced to a regular diet. The patient has allergies to antibiotics and is on various medications. Her vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 86 bpm and blood pressure ranging from 129/58 mmHg to 141/67 mmHg. She is oxygenating well at 100% saturation. Her review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted improvements. The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, low platelet count, and other abnormalities consistent with alcoholic hepatitis and acute renal failure. The patient is being treated for hepatic encephalopathy, GI bleeding, leukocytosis, hypotension, shock, metabolic acidosis, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and a history of anorexia/bulimia. She is on multiple medications and has ongoing monitoring and follow-up plans.

   Assessment and Plan:
   45 yo female with history of eating disorders, ETOH cirrhosis here with
   fulminant hepatic failure, GIB, acute renal failure, and shock found to
   have alcoholic hepatitis.
   .
   # Alcoholic hepatitis :  Despite her recent discriminant function>32,
   opted not to treat with any steroids given her marked GI bleeding (
   esophageal varices oozing & banded after EGD on [**3-16**]).  Total bilirubin
   continues to be elevated but has now dipped from 30 to 28 range today.
   INR still elevated at 2. 1 today. All recent  hepatitis studies,
   ceruloplasmin, SMA & IGG all negative for any alternative hepatitis
   causes and social history of recent heavy ETOH use most consistent with
   alcoholic hepatitis.
   - start nadolol today with hold parameters
   - continue pentoxyphylline, holding off on steroids for now
   -  f/up liver recs
   - continue lactulose / rifaxamin
   - continue last day of Cipro ( day 5 of  5 )
   - trending Hcts  [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue MVI, thiamine, daily folate
   - SW consult when more stable
   #Hepatic encephalopathy:  Now on lactulose and rifaximin, appears more
   awake after extubation. No evidence of cerebral edema on recent CT
   head. No additional questionable clonic motions or posturing overnight.
   -  consider MRI once stabilized given note of right orbital nonspecific
   finding on CT
   -  [**Hospital1 **]  neuro checks at this point
   - continue lactulose
   #GI Bleeding:  She had urgent EGD on arrival and is now s/p banding of
   esophageal varices. No hemetemesis or melena overnight.  Blood
   pressures still continue to remain stable off of pressors.
   - keep active T&S
   - can switch to [**Hospital1 **] HCT checks now , transfuse to > 25 Hct
   - s/p 3 days of octreotide drip which ended [**3-18**]
   - continue protonix IV BID
   #Leukocytosis:  Still no fever spikes despite WBC climb up to 20 range
   today. No evidence of active respiratory infection.  CXR with opacity
   on right. Otherwise, as above, her workup was negative for SBP.  Should
   have adequate coverage for her UTI as OSH micro data showed
   pan-sensitive E.Coli. Sputum cx mixed bacteria.
   - discontinue vanc/cefepime today
   - follow for fevers / WBC trend
   - continue Cipro
   - repeat blood cultures if spikes
   - consider repeat sputum cultures
   .. .
   #Metabolic Acidosis:  Continues to improve. Likely related to renal
   failure and elevated lactate. Anion Gap coming down to 15-range now (
   from 20s) .
   -follow AG trend, electrolytes, Cr and ABG compensation
   -renal recs appreciated
   .
   #ARF: Improved with IVF arguing for prerenal component. Likely volume
   deplete [**1-5**] GIB and poor PO. She is now having  adequate urine output
   and her  Cr down to 2.4 today with some additional IVFs over past day.
   Watch closely as can have post ATN diuresis
   - renal following, no indication for HD as Cr decreasing
   - continue to trend urine output, Cr
   - watch I/Os,  goal to run even today
   - check lytes [**Hospital1 **]
   - f/up renal recs
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia:  Most likely secondary to chronic liver diasease and
   may be element of additional marrow suppression ETOH use.
   - keep platelets above 10 unless any active bleeding, transfuse plts as
   needed
   - follow cbc daily
   ..
   #History of anorexia/bulimia: Confirmed with sister and father. Unclear
   if patient is actively abusing laxatives.
   - monitor electrolytes as above
   - SW consult once more stable

   Nutrition:  PO regular diet now, continue tube feeds

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old female with a history of eating disorders, ETOH cirrhosis, fulminant hepatic failure, gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), acute renal failure, and shock. She has been diagnosed with alcoholic hepatitis and is currently being treated in the ICU. The patient's recent discriminant function value was greater than 32, so steroids were not administered. Her total bilirubin levels are still elevated but have decreased from 30 to 28 range today. The patient is on lactulose and rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy, nadolol for portal hypertension, pentoxyphylline for liver health, and continuing with last day of Cipro. The patient also has thrombocytopenia, metabolic acidosis, and ARF. She is being closely monitored for various conditions and complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient is on lactulose and rifaximin, which are appropriate treatments for hepatic encephalopathy. It is important to continue monitoring her mental status and neurologic checks.
2. GI bleeding: Although the patient has been stabilized with banding of esophageal varices, there is still a risk of re-bleeding. Active T&S and HCT checks should be continued.
3. Leukocytosis: Although the patient's WBC count is elevated, there is no fever or evidence of active infection.

Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old female admitted with altered mental status, alcoholic hepatitis, and gastrointestinal bleeding. She has been improving steadily since extubation, with a stable mental status and no longer intubated. The patient's sputum production suggests a possible infiltrate on chest X-ray, so she was started on antibiotics empirically. She received a liter of lactated Ringer's bolus to maintain positive fluid balance and advanced to a regular diet last night.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient shows signs of improvement with the use of lactulose and rifaximin. However, ongoing monitoring is necessary due to the presence of right orbital findings on CT.
2. GI bleeding: The patient underwent an urgent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and is now stable after banding of esophageal varices. Continuous monitoring for any signs of rebleeding is essential.
3. Leukocytosis: Despite the elevated white blood cell count, there are no fever spikes or evidence of active respiratory infection. The patient should be closely monitored for any signs of infection, and sputum cultures may be repeated.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's condition is improving, likely related to renal failure and elevated lactate levels. Close follow-up of anion gap, electrolytes, creatinine, and ABG compensation is necessary.
5. Acute renal failure (ARF):

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old female who was admitted with altered mental status (AMS), alcoholic hepatitis, and gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). She was extubated and is now maintaining on room air. Her mental status has improved, and she is more alert and interactive. She is producing sputum, which may indicate an infiltrate on the chest X-ray, so she has been started on empiric antibiotics. The patient received a liter of normal saline bolus to maintain a positive fluid balance and has advanced to a regular diet.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The presence of sputum production and an infiltrate on the chest X-ray suggests the possibility of pneumonia. The patient has already been started on empiric antibiotics, which is appropriate for treating pneumonia.

2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: Although the patient was initially admitted with GIB, there is no mention of ongoing bleeding in the progress note. However, it is important to monitor for any signs of recurrent bleeding.

3. Hepatic encephalopathy: Given the patient's history of alcoholic hepatitis, there is a risk of hepatic encephalopathy. This can cause altered mental status, so it should be considered as a potential cause of her initial AMS.

4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and hospitalization increase the risk of developing DVT. Prophylaxis has been ordered, but it is still important to monitor for symptoms such as swelling

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 45-year-old female with a history of ETOH cirrhosis who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant liver failure. The patient's condition is complicated by potential infection versus increased alcohol consumption. 

The patient's recent events include being extubated without complications, gradual improvement in mental status, increased sputum production, increased white blood cell count, and tolerance of advancing diet to a regular diet. 

The patient has allergies to ciprofloxacin and is currently receiving vancomycin, cefepime, and pantoprazole. 

Her vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure ranging from 104/61 mmHg to 134/65 mmHg, heart rate of 85 bpm, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 3,579 mL and output of 3,205 mL over 24 hours. 

Physical examination findings include thinness, confusion, scleral icterus, poor dentition, clear breath sounds, right lower extremity edema, left lower extremity edema, muscle wasting, cool skin, and decreased tone. 

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 20.1 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, sodium of 123 mg/dL, potassium of 2.0 mg/dL, chloride of 60 mg/dL, bicarbonate of 27.4%, magnesium of 3.3 mEq/L, blood urea nitrogen of 116 mEq/L, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, glucose of 123 mg/dL, and albumin of 3.2 g/dL. 

Based on the assessment and plan, the patient has ETOH cirrhosis with gradual improvement in bilirubin/MELD score but persistent encephalopathy. The plan includes continuing penitentilyline, lactulose for encephalopathy, social work assistance, neurologic checks, and starting nadolol due to history of gastrointestinal bleeding and changing proton pump inhibitor to oral. 

The patient also has leukocytosis, respiratory failure, and renal failure. The respiratory failure is improving with tolerance of room air. Renal failure is improving with hydration and will require nephrology input. 

The patient is tolerating a regular diet and ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, arterial and PICC lines, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. 

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of multiple organ dysfunctions.
